   Assessment and Plan
   24 yo M with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to CCU after failure
   to extubate s/p elective AICD placement and right heart cath.
   .
   # Failure to extubate: Patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU
   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization on
   [**1-8**]. Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid
   obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume
   overload from patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading
   to elevated elastic pressures. ABG initially showed chronic respiratory
   acidosis with appropriate metabolic compensation, may be due to obesity
   hypoventilation/Pickwickian syndrome, but repeat ABG showed normal
   gas.  Initially pt was diuresed with lasix gtt (40 mg IV bolus x1),
   which was held in the setting of hypotension and poor UOP.  Patient was
   put on Assist Control throughout the night here in CCU, and PEEP was
   down-titrated from 12 to 8 with good oxygenation.
   - change from AC to pressure support
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - wean ventilator as tolerated
   - start lasix diuresis once pt is off pressor
   - attempt to extubate this am
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After arriving on
   the CCU floor, non-invasive approach revealed BP in the 90-100s/40s.
   However, patient had no UOP to lasix bolus and gtt, so A-line was
   placed. Placement of A-line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating relative
   hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical ventilation which
   are more likely given the acute change versus sepsis given recent
   diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of keflex, fever noted on
   CCU admission, hypotension, and decreased urine output.  Patient was
   started on neo gtt for MAP>65.  Lasix gtt was held. PEEP was turned
   down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.
   - turn off neo this morning and see if pt can maintain BP on his own
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - extubate today if possible
   - hold placement of CVL for now given possible extubation this AM; will
   place if pressor requirements increase.
   - f/u blood and urine cultures
   - check  c. diff toxin assay
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cre up to 1.7 on admission and up to 2.1 this AM
   (baseline 1.1).  Patient relatively oliguric on admission to the CCU
   with only 40 ccs of dark urine output to 20 of IV lasix administered in
   the PACU.   After lasix gtt was started last night, UOP was close to
   zero.  After neo was started, UOP finally picked up after a few hours.
   At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most likely pre-renal in setting of
   hypotension during the procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to
   ATN (intrarenal).  FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other
   etiologies (though less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of
   depressed EF% versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent
   contrast administration.
   - turn off neo and see if he can maintain BP on his own
   - renal consult this AM
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4
   overnight. Likely febrile in setting of recent procedure. Hypotension,
   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning
   for possible sepsis.  UA is negative.
   - f/u blood cultures, urine cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Hyperbilirubinemia: Long-standing but bilirubin is very high at 2.7
   this am. Etiologies include [**Doctor Last Name **] syndrome, fatty liver and biliary
   stasis, CHF and biliary stasis, acalculous cholecystitis, gallstone
   cholecystitis. Patient sedated with propofol overnight given quick
   on/off for sedation. Patient received fentanyl and versed but was
   reportedly not well sedated during the procedure on this regimen,
   resulting in switch to propofol. Per discussion with pharmacy, OK to
   sedate with propofol temporarily overnight (12 hours) if extubation
   planned this AM.
   - f/u on direct and indirect bili
   - consider RUQ US
   - trend LFTs daily
   .
   # PUMP: Non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, thought to be viral in
   etiology. Likely has chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure (EF
   25% on [**9-28**].) Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC
   today with severe pulmonary hypertension. Patient received lasix 20 mg
   IV x1 in PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then
   held in the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were
   ~20 pts lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output.
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - fluid restriction, low Na diet, strict Is and Os, foley, daily
   weights
   - continue BB, digoxin
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient is s/p AICD placement for primary prevention of
   tachyarrythmias given non-ischemic cardiomyopathy EF of 25%. One
   episode of NSVT in the CCU.  Dig level 0.9 this am.
   - will need PA/lateral CXR once pt is extubated to check lead position
   - EP to interrogate pacer in AM
   - replete K > 4 Mg > 2
   - continue beta-blocker and digoxin
   .
   # CORONARIES: No known hx of CAD.
   - continue ASA, beta-blocker
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] in setting acute renal failure
   .
   # Asthma:
   - albuterol inhaler prn
   .
   # Anemia: Known iron deficiency anemia.
   - Trend Hct.
   - Continue iron supplements with bowel regimen and vitamin C once able
   to take PO.
   .
   # OSA:
   - restart/encourage nocturnal CPAP at home once extubated.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NPO for now
   Glycemic Control:  not on insulin
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2193-1-8**] 10:00 PM
   18 Gauge - [**2193-1-8**] 10:56 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2193-1-9**] 02:03 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Need for restraints reviewed
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU
Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate post-elective AICD placement and right heart cath. He has several medical complications that require attention:

1. Failure to extubate: The patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU following ICD placement, EP study, and right heart cardiac catheterization. This could be due to extrapulmonary restriction (morbid obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume overload from the patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading to elevated elastic pressures. The ABG initially showed chronic respiratory acidosis with appropriate metabolic compensation, possibly due to obesity hypoventilation/Pickwickian syndrome, but the repeat ABG showed normal gases. The plan is to change from AC to pressure support, decrease and wean off propofol, wean ventilator as tolerated, start lasix diuresis once the patient is off pressor, and attempt to extubate this morning.

2. Hypotension: The patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After arriving on the CCU floor, non-invasive BP readings were in the 90-100s/40s. However, the patient had no UOP after lasix bolus and gtt, so an arterial line was placed. Placement of A-line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating

Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. The patient has a history of chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure, with elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC. He is currently on mechanical ventilation, with an endotracheal tube in place, and has been sedated with propofol. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 101.4°F, heart rate of 100 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 90-100s/40s, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient has been diagnosed with hypotension, fever, acute renal failure, hyperbilirubinemia, and a history of anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Failure to extubate: The patient's inability to be extubated may be due to extrapulmonary restriction (morbid obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance resulting from volume overload caused by systolic and diastolic heart failure.

2. Hypotension: The patient's low blood pressure could be attributed to several factors, including sedation/mechanical ventilation, sepsis (given recent diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of keflex), fever noted on CCU admission, or cardiogenic causes which are less

   Assessment and Plan
   24 yo M with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to CCU after failure
   to extubate s/p elective AICD placement and right heart cath.
   .
   # Failure to extubate: Patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU
   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization on
   [**1-8**]. Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid
   obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume
   overload from patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading
   to elevated elastic pressures. ABG initially showed chronic respiratory
   acidosis with appropriate metabolic compensation, may be due to obesity
   hypoventilation/Pickwickian syndrome, but repeat ABG showed normal
   gas.  Initially pt was diuresed with lasix gtt (40 mg IV bolus x1),
   which was held in the setting of hypotension and poor UOP.  Patient was
   put on Assist Control throughout the night here in CCU, and PEEP was
   down-titrated from 12 to 8 with good oxygenation.
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - wean ventilator as tolerated
   - start lasix diuresis once pt is off pressor
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After arriving on
   the CCU floor, non-invasive approach revealed BP in the 90-100s/40s.
   However, patient had no UOP to lasix bolus and gtt, so A-line was
   placed. Placement of A-line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating relative
   hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical ventilation versus
   sepsis given recent diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of
   keflex, fever noted on CCU admission, hypotension, and decreased urine
   output.  Patient was started on neo gtt for MAP>65.  Lasix gtt was
   held. PEEP was turned down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.
   - turn off neo this morning and see if pt can maintain BP on his own
   - extubate today if possible
   - hold placement of CVL for now given possible extubation this AM; will
   place if pressor requirements increase.
   - f/u blood and urine cultures
   - check  c. diff toxin assay
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cre up to 1.7 on admission and up to 2.1 this AM
   (baseline 1.1).  Patient relatively oliguric on admission to the CCU
   with only 40 ccs of dark urine output to 20 of IV lasix administered in
   the PACU.   After lasix gtt was started last night, UOP was close to
   zero.  After neo was started, UOP finally picked up after a few hours.
   At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most likely pre-renal in setting of
   hypotension during the procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to
   ATN (intrarenal).  FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other
   etiologies (though less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of
   depressed EF% versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent
   contrast administration.
   - turn off neo and see if he can maintain BP on his own
   - renal consult this AM
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4
   overnight. Likely febrile in setting of recent procedure. Hypotension,
   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning
   for possible sepsis.  UA is negative.
   - f/u blood cultures, urine cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Hyperbilirubinemia: Long-standing but bilirubin is very high at 2.7
   this am. Etiologies include [**Doctor Last Name **] syndrome, fatty liver and biliary
   stasis, CHF and biliary stasis, acalculous cholecystitis, gallstone
   cholecystitis. Patient sedated with propofol overnight given quick
   on/off for sedation. Patient received fentanyl and versed but was
   reportedly not well sedated during the procedure on this regimen,
   resulting in switch to propofol. Per discussion with pharmacy, OK to
   sedate with propofol temporarily overnight (12 hours) if extubation
   planned this AM.
   - f/u on direct and indirect bili
   - consider RUQ US
   - trend LFTs daily
   .
   # PUMP: Non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, thought to be viral in
   etiology. Likely has chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure (EF
   25% on [**9-28**].) Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC
   today with severe pulmonary hypertension. Patient received lasix 20 mg
   IV x1 in PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then
   held in the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were
   ~20 pts lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output.
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - fluid restriction, low Na diet, strict Is and Os, foley, daily
   weights
   - continue BB, digoxin
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient is s/p AICD placement for primary prevention of
   tachyarrythmias given non-ischemic cardiomyopathy EF of 25%. One
   episode of NSVT in the CCU.  Dig level 0.9 this am.
   - will need PA/lateral CXR once pt is extubated to check lead position
   - EP to interrogate pacer in AM
   - replete K > 4 Mg > 2
   - continue beta-blocker and digoxin
   .
   # CORONARIES: No known hx of CAD.
   - continue ASA, beta-blocker
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] in setting acute renal failure
   .
   # Asthma:
   - albuterol inhaler prn
   .
   # Anemia: Known iron deficiency anemia.
   - Trend Hct.
   - Continue iron supplements with bowel regimen and vitamin C once able
   to take PO.
   .
   # OSA:
   - restart/encourage nocturnal CPAP at home once extubated.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NPO for now
   Glycemic Control:  not on insulin

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy who was admitted to the CCU after failing to extubate following elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He is currently intubated, sedated, and on mechanical ventilation with PEEP at 8 cmH2O. The patient has a history of obesity, systolic and diastolic heart failure, and recent cellulitis treated with cephalexin. He presented with hypotension and oliguria upon admission, which improved with neo and weaning off propofol. His urine output increased to 250cc/hr after starting neo. The patient also has elevated creatinine levels, indicating acute renal failure. His bilirubin level is high, and he is febrile with a temperature of 101.4°F. The patient has a history of asthma, anemia, and obstructive sleep apnea.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Failure to wean off mechanical ventilation: The patient's inability to be extubated post-procedure suggests the possibility of respiratory complications such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Hypotension and shock: The patient's initial hypotension and oliguria raise concerns for septic shock, especially given his recent infection and fever.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The elevated creatinine levels and oliguria indicate possible AKI, which could be pre-renal due to hypotension or intrinsic renal injury.
4. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient's high bilirubin level requires further evaluation for potential causes such as biliary stasis, cholecystitis, or liver dysfunction.
5. Fever: The patient's fever could be indicative of an ongoing infection or inflammatory response, necessitating further investigation and appropriate antibiotic coverage.
6. Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS): Given the patient's morbid obesity and chronic respiratory acidosis, OHS should be considered and managed accordingly.
7. Cardiac complications: As a patient with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, he is at risk for further cardiac events like arrhythmias or worsening heart failure.

Please note that this summary and potential complications are based solely on the information provided in the progress note. Additional clinical information and tests may be necessary for a comprehensive assessment.

Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate post-elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. The patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU, likely due to extrapulmonary restriction (morbid obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume overload from the patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading to elevated elastic pressures. The ABG initially showed chronic respiratory acidosis with appropriate metabolic compensation, possibly due to obesity hypoventilation/Pickwickian syndrome, but a repeat ABG showed normal gas exchange.

The patient had hypotension pre-procedure with a SBP of 140s, but after arriving in the CCU floor, non-invasive BP readings were in the 90-100s/40s. An arterial line was placed, showing SBPs of 70s, indicating relative hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical ventilation versus sepsis given recent diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of Keflex, fever noted on CCU admission, hypotension, and decreased urine output. The patient was started on neo gtt for MAP>65. PEEP was turned down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.

The patient also has acute renal failure with a creatinine level up to 2.1 (baseline 1.1). The patient was oliguric on admission to the CCU with only 40 ccs of dark urine output to 20 of IV lasix administered in the PACU. After starting lasix gtt, UOP was close to zero. After neo was started, UOP finally picked up after a few hours, reaching 250cc/hr at 6am. The most likely etiology is pre-renal in setting of hypotension during the procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to ATN (intrarenal). 

The patient also has a fever with a temperature of 101.2 on arrival to CCU, which spiked to 101.4 overnight. This could be due to recent procedure-related infection or sepsis. Blood cultures, urine cultures, and CXR are pending. The patient has hyperbilirubinemia with bilirubin levels very high at 2.7 this am. Possible etiologies include [Doctor Last Name] syndrome, fatty liver, biliary stasis, CHF, and biliary stasis, acalculous cholecystitis, gallstone cholecystitis. 

The patient has non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, thought to be viral in etiology. He has chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure (EF 25% on [9-28]). Elevated left and right heart pressures were noted on RHC today with severe pulmonary hypertension. The patient received lasix

   which was held in the setting of hypotension and poor UOP.  Patient was
   put on Assist Control throughout the night here in CCU, and PEEP was
   down-titrated from 12 to 8 with good oxygenation.
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - wean ventilator as tolerated
   - start lasix diuresis once pt is off pressor
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After arriving on
   the CCU floor, non-invasive approach revealed BP in the 90-100s/40s.
   However, patient had no UOP to lasix bolus and gtt, so A-line was
   placed. Placement of A-line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating relative
   hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical ventilation versus
   sepsis given recent diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of
   keflex, fever noted on CCU admission, hypotension, and decreased urine
   output.  Patient was started on neo gtt for MAP>65.  Lasix gtt was
   held. PEEP was turned down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.
   - turn off neo this morning and see if pt can maintain BP on his own
   - extubate today if possible
   - hold placement of CVL for now given possible extubation this AM; will
   place if pressor requirements increase.
   - f/u blood and urine cultures
   - check  c. diff toxin assay
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .

   (baseline 1.1).  Patient relatively oliguric on admission to the CCU
   with only 40 ccs of dark urine output to 20 of IV lasix administered in
   the PACU.   After lasix gtt was started last night, UOP was close to
   zero.  After neo was started, UOP finally picked up after a few hours.
   At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most likely pre-renal in setting of
   hypotension during the procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to
   ATN (intrarenal).  FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other
   etiologies (though less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of
   depressed EF% versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent

   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning

   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .

   etiology. Likely has chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure (EF
   25% on [**9-28**].) Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC
   today with severe pulmonary hypertension. Patient received lasix 20 mg
   IV x1 in PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then
   held in the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were
   ~20 pts lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output.

   - EP to interrogate pacer in AM

   - continue ASA, beta-blocker

   # Hyperbilirubinemia: Long-standing but bilirubin is very high at 2.7
   this am. Etiologies include [**Doctor Last Name **] syndrome, fatty liver and biliary
   stasis, CHF and biliary stasis, acalculous cholecystitis, gallstone
   cholecystitis. Patient sedated with propofol overnight given quick
   on/off for sedation. Patient received fentanyl and versed but was
   reportedly not well sedated during the procedure on this regimen,
   resulting in switch to propofol. Per discussion with pharmacy, OK to
   sedate with propofol temporarily overnight (12 hours) if extubation
   planned this AM.

   .

   .

   .

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. The patient is currently intubated and sedated, with a fever of 101.4. He has been diagnosed with acute renal failure, hypotension, and an elevated creatinine level of 2.1. Other findings include hyperbilirubinemia, anemia, and obesity with associated complications such as morbid obesity, pitting edema, venous stasis changes, and a large body habitus. The patient's medical history includes asthma, OSA, iron deficiency anemia, and chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 25%. He is currently receiving various medications including diuretics, vasopressors, antibiotics, and anticoagulants.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and oliguric output indicate possible acute renal failure. This could be due to pre-renal causes such as hypotension during the procedure or intrinsic renal damage. Further evaluation and management are required, including holding lasix gtt and consulting a nephrologist.

2. Hypotension: The patient's low blood pressure readings throughout the ICU stay suggest hypotension. This could be attributed to sedation, mechanical ventilation, sepsis

Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with a history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy who was admitted to the CCU after failing to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart cath. The patient's current medical complications include failure to extubate, hypotension, acute renal failure, fever, hyperbilirubinemia, and dilated cardiomyopathy with severe pulmonary hypertension. 

Failure to extubate: The patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU following ICD placement, EP study, and right heart cardiac catherization. It is likely due to extrapulmonary restriction (morbid obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance caused by volume overload from the patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading to elevated elastic pressures. 

Hypotension: The patient had a pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After arriving in the CCU, non-invasive BP readings were in the 90-100s/40s. However, the patient had no urine output to lasix bolus and gtt, so an arterial line was placed. Placement of the arterial line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating relative hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical ventilation, sepsis, or cardiogenic causes. 

Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level increased from 1.1 to 2.1 this morning

   24 yo M with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to CCU after failure
   to extubate s/p elective AICD placement and right heart cath.
   .
   # Failure to extubate: Patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU
   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization.
   Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid obesity/large
   body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume overload from
   patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading to elevated
   elastic pressures. ABG initially showed chronic respiratory acidosis
   with appropriate metabolic compensation, may be due to obesity
   hypoventilation/Pickwickian syndrome, but repeat ABG showed normal
   gas.  Initially pt was diuresed with lasix gtt (40 mg IV bolus x1),
   which was held in the setting of hypotension and poor UOP.  Patient was
   put on Assist Control throughout the night here in CCU, and PEEP was
   down-titrated from 12 to 8 with good oxygenation.
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - wean ventilator as tolerated
   - start lasix diuresis once pt is off pressor
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After arriving on
   the CCU floor, non-invasive approach revealed BP in the 90-100s/40s.
   However, patient had no UOP to lasix bolus and gtt, so A-line was
   placed. Placement of A-line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating relative
   hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical ventilation versus
   sepsis given recent diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of
   keflex, fever noted on CCU admission, hypotension, and decreased urine
   output.  Patient was started on neo gtt for MAP>65.  Lasix gtt was
   held. PEEP was turned down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.
   - turn off neo this morning and see if pt can maintain BP on his own
   - extubate today if possible
   - hold placement of CVL for now given possible extubation this AM; will
   place if pressor requirements increase.
   - f/u blood and urine cultures
   - check  c. diff toxin assay
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cre up to 1.7 on admission and up to 2.1 this AM
   (baseline 1.1).  Patient relatively oliguric on admission to the CCU
   with only 40 ccs of dark urine output to 20 of IV lasix administered in
   the PACU.   After lasix gtt was started last night, UOP was close to
   zero.  After neo was started, UOP finally picked up after a few hours.
   At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most likely pre-renal in setting of
   hypotension during the procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to
   ATN (intrarenal).  FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other
   etiologies (though less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of
   depressed EF% versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent
   contrast administration.
   - turn off neo and see if he can maintain BP on his own
   - renal consult this AM
   - hold lasix gtt for now
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4
   overnight. Likely febrile in setting of recent procedure. Hypotension,
   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning
   for possible sepsis.  UA is negative.
   - f/u blood cultures, urine cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and cefepime)
   .
   # PUMP: Non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, thought to be viral in
   etiology. Likely has chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure (EF
   25% on [**9-28**].) Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC
   today with severe pulmonary hypertension. Patient received lasix 20 mg
   IV x1 in PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then
   held in the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were

Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. The patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU. 

The patient has several medical complications that need attention:
1. Failure to wean from mechanical ventilation: The patient is currently on assist control ventilation and PEEP has been down-titrated from 12 to 8 with good oxygenation. The plan is to decrease and wean off propofol, wean ventilator as tolerated, and start lasix diuresis once the patient is off pressor.
2. Hypotension: The patient initially had a systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 140s, but after arriving in the CCU, the SBP was in the 90-100s/40s. The patient had no urine output (UOP) after receiving lasix bolus and gtt, so an arterial line was placed. The SBPs were in the 70s, indicating relative hypotension. Possible etiologies include sedation/ventilation versus sepsis. The patient was started on neo gtt for MAP > 65, and PEEP was turned down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation. The plan is to turn off neo this morning and see if the patient can maintain BP on his own, extubate today

Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with a history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate post-elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. The patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU, s/p ICD placement, EP study, and right heart cardiac catherization on [**1-8**]. 

The patient has several medical complications that need attention. 

1. Failure to extubate: The patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU. This may be due to extrapulmonary restriction (morbid obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume overload from the patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading to elevated elastic pressures. 

2. Hypotension: The patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After arriving on the CCU floor, non-invasive BP revealed BP in the 90-100s/40s. However, the patient had no UOP to lasix bolus and gtt, so an arterial line was placed. Placement of the arterial line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating relative hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical ventilation, sepsis, cardiogenic, or other causes. 

3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels have increased from 1.1 to 2.1

Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with a history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, who was admitted to the CCU after failing to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart cath. He has profound biventricular systolic dysfunction, likely secondary to prior heavy cocaine use, viral or alcoholic etiology. His ejection fraction (EF) is severely depressed, and his left ventricular stroke work capacity is profoundly reduced. The patient's morbid obesity and history of substance abuse make cardiac transplantation candidacy questionable.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Heart Failure: The patient has a history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with profound biventricular systolic dysfunction, leading to systolic and diastolic heart failure. This increases the risk of complications such as pulmonary edema, hypotension, renal dysfunction, and arrhythmias.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient initially presented with oliguric renal failure with a creatinine level of 1.7, which improved to 1.7 today. This may be due to pre-renal causes such as hypotension during procedures or overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. Other etiologies include poor forward flow due to depressed EF% or contrast nephropathy.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy and a history of cocaine use, admitted to the ICU after failing to extubate post-elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. The patient has profound biventricular systolic dysfunction, likely secondary to prior heavy cocaine use, viral infection, or alcoholic abuse. His ejection fraction (EF) is severely depressed at 10%, and his left ventricular stroke work capacity is profoundly reduced. The patient's situation is grave, and his candidacy for cardiac transplantation is questionable due to morbid obesity and substance abuse.

The patient's current condition includes:
1. Failure to extubate: The patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU after ICD placement, EP study, and right heart cardiac catheterization. He has elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC, severe pulmonary hypertension, and poor urine output. The patient has been transitioned from AC to CPAP and will continue with gentle diuresis.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient had an elevated creatinine level of 1.7 on admission and 2.1 on [1-9], which is improving. He was oliguric initially but responded well to neo and diuretics. The likely etiology is pre-renal due to hypotension during procedures, leading to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Medications will be renally dosed, and nephrotoxins will be avoided.
3. Fever: The patient had a temperature of 101.2 on arrival to the CCU and spiked to 101.4 on [1-8]. He is febrile in the setting of recent procedures with traumatic intubation. The most likely causes are aspiration pneumonitis or pneumonia. Sputum gram stain shows several species, and blood cultures are pending. The patient will continue on broad coverage antibiotics.
4. Rhythm: The patient has a history of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) in the CCU and has undergone AICD placement for primary prevention of tachyarrhythmias. Digoxin levels are within normal range, and beta-blockers and digoxin will be continued.
5. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient has long-standing hyperbilirubinemia with a bilirubin level of 2.7 on [1-8]. The most likely etiology is congestive hepatopathy due to chronic heart failure.
6. Hypotension: The patient initially had stable blood pressure but later developed hypotension in the 70s/40s, which was initially attributed to sedation and mechanical ventilation. Other potential causes include sepsis or cardiogenic shock. The patient was started on neo gtt for mean arterial pressure (MAP) >65, and lasix gtt was held.
7. Coronaries: No known history of coronary artery disease (CAD). Coronary catheterization will provide definitive information. Continue ASA and beta-blocker therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's severely depressed EF and reduced left ventricular stroke work capacity indicate a high risk of cardiogenic shock.
2. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's poor lung compliance and elevated elastic pressures suggest a risk of developing ARDS, especially if he develops pneumonia or aspiration pneumonitis.
3. Hepatic dysfunction: The patient's hyperbilirubinemia and elevated liver enzymes indicate potential hepatic dysfunction, which could be due to congestive hepatopathy or other causes.
4. Renal failure: The patient's initial acute renal failure with elevated creatinine levels indicates a risk of further renal dysfunction.
5. Infection: The patient's fever and positive sputum gram stain suggest a risk of infection, possibly pneumonia or aspiration pneumonitis.
6. Thromboembolic events: The patient's immobility and hypercoagulable state increase his risk for thromboembolic events such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE). Prophylactic measures such as subcutaneous unfractionated heparin are in place.

   Imaging: CXR [**1-9**]
    In comparison with the study of [**1-8**], there are very low lung volumes.
   Huge enlargement of the cardiac silhouette persists. Pulmonary vessels
   are difficult to evaluate, though they do not appear to be especially
   engorged. The AICD line extends to the region of the apex of the right
   ventricle. The area behind the hugely enlarged heart cannot be
   evaluated for the possible presence of pneumonia or effusion
   ECHO [**1-9**]
   The left atrium is moderately dilated. The right atrium is moderately
   dilated. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left
   ventricular cavity is severely dilated. Due to suboptimal technical
   quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded.
   Overall left ventricular systolic function is probably severely
   depressed (LVEF 20%??) but views are suboptimal for assessment of wall
   motion. The right ventricular cavity is dilated with depressed free
   wall contractility. The aortic valve is not well seen. The mitral valve
   leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen.
   There is at least mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is
   a small pericardial effusion (seen largely posteriorly). There are no
   echocardiographic signs of tamponade. Echocardiographic signs of
   tamponade may be absent in the presence of elevated right sided
   pressures.
   ABD US [**1-9**]
   Evaluation is slightly limited by patient's
   size. Within this limitation, the liver echotexture is unremarkable.
   There
   is no intra- or extra-hepatic biliary ductal dilatation, and the common
   bile
   duct measures 6 mm. Main portal vein is patent with hepatopetal flow.
   There
   is no ascites. The gallbladder is not identified. The spleen measures
   11.7
   cm.

   Sputum Gram Stain
         >25 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field.
         2+   (1-5 per 1000X FIELD):   GRAM POSITIVE COCCI.
                                       IN PAIRS, CHAINS, AND CLUSTERS.
         2+   (1-5 per 1000X FIELD):   GRAM NEGATIVE ROD(S).
         1+    (<1 per 1000X FIELD):   GRAM NEGATIVE DIPLOCOCCI.
   Assessment and Plan
   24 yo M with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to CCU after failure
   to extubate s/p elective AICD placement and right heart cath.
   .
   # CHF, systolic and exacerbated. profound biventricular systolic
   dysfunction, presumably secondary to prior heavy cocaine use in year
   prior to CHF diagnosis.  Also possibly viral (was tested at time of
   diagnosis and only positive for RSV) or alcoholic (patient endorses
   weekend binges at most). TTE of [**1-9**] shows EF of 10% that may be an
   overestimate. His situation is grave, as his LV stroke work capacity is
   so profoundly reduced.  His morbid obesity and history of substance
   abuse makes cardiac transplantation candidacy questionable.
   PLAN per Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
   -  attempt a definitive dx before implementing maximal therapy
   -  Thererfore we will do left and right heart cath, endomyocardial bx,
   and pulmonary arterioloar vasodilator trila irf PVR is > 4 [**Doctor Last Name 2576**] units.
   -  Thereafter we will leave SGC in place and do tailored therapy
   - continue bb, digoxin, fluid restriction, and when appropriate, a low
   Na diet
   .
   # Failure to extubate: Patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU
   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization on
   [**1-8**]. Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid
   obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume
   overload from patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading
   to elevated elastic pressures. ABG initially showed chronic respiratory
   acidosis with appropriate metabolic compensation, may be due to obesity
   hypoventilation/Pickwickian syndrome, but repeat ABG showed normal
   gas.  Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC [**1-8**] with
   severe pulmonary hypertension; Patient received lasix 20 mg IV x1 in
   PACU and 40 IV x1 in CCU followed by lasix gtt, which was then held in
   the setting of hypotension noted on A-line readings (which were ~20 pts
   lower than non-invasive readings) and poor urine output. On [**1-9**], UOP
   briskly responded to brief time on phenylephrine.  Patient was put on
   was transitioned from AC to CPAP on [**1-9**].
   - modify vent settings as needed
   - decrease and wean off propofol
   - wean ventilator as tolerated
   - patient with excellent urine output; can diurese gently as plan
   regarding heart becomes clear
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Resolving. Cre up to 1.7 on admission and up to
   2.1 on [**1-9**] (baseline 1.1). Improving to 1.7 today  Patient relatively
   oliguric on admission to the CCU with only 40 ccs of dark urine output
   to 20 of IV lasix administered in the PACU.   After lasix gtt was
   started last night, UOP was close to zero.  After neo was started, UOP
   finally picked up after a few hours.  At 6am, UOP was 250cc/hr. Most
   likely, his ARF was pre-renal in setting of hypotension during the
   procedure due to sedation/intubation, leading to ATN (intrarenal).
   FeUrea is 10, indicating pre-renal etiology. Other etiologies (though
   less likely) include poor forward flow in setting of depressed EF%
   versus overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. No recent contrast
   administration.
   -  hold lasix gtt for now
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4 on [**1-8**].
   Likely febrile in setting of recent procedure with traumatic
   intubation. Most likely aspiration pneumonitis or (less likely)
   pneumonia). Sputum gram stain with several species. Hypotension,
   although more likely due to sedation/intubation is somewhat concerning
   for possible sepsis.  UA negative. Blood cx pending. RUQ US: No
   gallbladder, no cholecystitis
   - f/u blood cultures, urine cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - continue broad coverage abx ( vanc and levo). Likely switch to
   regular vanc dosing from level-dosing. Receiving 1.5 g this AM.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient is s/p AICD placement for primary prevention of
   tachyarrythmias given non-ischemic cardiomyopathy EF of 10%
   (presently). One episode of NSVT in the CCU.  Dig level 0.9 on [**1-9**].
   - will need PA/lateral CXR once pt is extubated to check lead position
   - replete K > 4 Mg > 2
   - continue beta-blocker and digoxin
   .
   # Hyperbilirubinemia: Long-standing but bilirubin is very high at 2.7
   on [**1-8**]. Etiologies include obstructive and infiltrative disease
   including congestive hepatopathy, fatty liver and biliary stasis,
   fibrosis and biliary stasis, and post-hepatic obstruction. Given fever,
   was ruled out for cholecystitis. This is most likely congestive.
   - trend liver enzymes
   .
   # Hypotension: Resolved. Patient had pre-procedure SBP of 140s. After
   arriving on the CCU floor, non-invasive approach revealed BP in the
   90-100s/40s.  However, patient had no UOP to lasix bolus and gtt, so
   A-line was placed. Placement of A-line showed SBPs of 70s, indicating
   relative hypotension. Etiologies include sedation/mechanical
   ventilation which are more likely given the acute change, sepsis given
   recent diagnosis of cellulitis treated with 10 days of keflex, fever
   noted on CCU admission, or cardiogenic which are less likely given the
   acute time course of events, i.e., his BP was good prior to the
   procedure.  Patient was started on neo gtt for MAP>65.  Lasix gtt was
   held. PEEP was turned down from 12 to 8 with adequate oxygenation.
   Patient weaned from Neo in the AM of [**1-9**].
   - decrease and wean off propofol as possible
   - f/u blood and urine cultures
   - check  c. diff toxin assay
   - continue broad coverage abx (vanc and levo)
   .
   # CORONARIES: No known hx of CAD.
   - cath will be definitive
   - continue ASA, beta-blocker
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] in setting acute renal failure
   .
   # Asthma:
   - ipratropium prn or albuterol
   .
   # Anemia: Known iron deficiency anemia.
   - Trend Hct.
   - Continue iron supplements with bowel regimen and vitamin C once able
   to take PO.
   .
   # OSA:
   - restart/encourage nocturnal CPAP at home once extubated.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, severe biventricular systolic dysfunction, and a history of cocaine use, viral or alcoholic etiology. He was admitted to the CCU after failing to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. His current condition is grave, with profound reduction in left ventricular stroke work capacity. The patient's morbid obesity and history of substance abuse raise questions about cardiac transplantation candidacy.

Medical Complications:
1. Failure to extubate: The patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU after ICD placement, EP study, and right heart cardiac catheterization on [**1-8**]. This could be due to extrapulmonary restriction (morbid obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume overload from systolic and diastolic heart failure.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient had a baseline creatinine of 1.1 and is now showing signs of acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 2.1. This could be due to hypotension during the procedure, leading to pre-renal azotemia, or possibly ATN.
3. Fever: The patient has had a fever since admission to the CCU, which could be due to aspiration pneumonitis or pneumonia. Sputum gram stain shows several species, and blood cultures are pending.

Summary:
The patient is a 70-inch-tall individual with an unknown weight, admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of high wedge pressures. The patient has a history of morbid obesity, drug use, and concern for ongoing alcohol use. They have been receiving furosemide (Lasix) at a rate of 5 mg/hour and propofol at 50 mcg/kg/min. The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature of 37.6 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 101 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 123/61 to 151/79 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the noted below.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Heart Failure: The high wedge pressures and concern for ongoing alcohol use may indicate heart failure. This condition can lead to fluid overload and pulmonary edema.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, indicating respiratory failure. This could be due to the underlying heart condition or other factors.
3. Sepsis: The heavy growth of GNRs in the sputum gram stain suggests a possible infection. Sepsis can lead to organ dysfunction and potentially worsen the patient's current condition.
4. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The presence of right lower extremity edema

Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. The patient has profound biventricular systolic dysfunction, likely secondary to prior heavy cocaine use, as well as possible viral or alcoholic etiologies. His left and right heart pressures are elevated, and he has severe pulmonary hypertension. The patient was transitioned from AC to CPAP on 1/9 and is currently on a lasix drip.

The patient's renal function is improving, with a creatinine level decreasing from 1.7 on admission to 1.6 today. He is oliguric on admission but now has adequate urine output on the lasix gtt. The most likely cause of his acute renal failure was pre-renal azotemia due to hypotension during the procedure. No recent contrast administration was noted.

The patient had a fever on arrival to the CCU, which has since resolved. He had an elevated temperature of 101.4 on 1/8. A sputum gram stain showed 2+ gram positive cocci, 2+ gram negative rods, and 1+ gram negative diplococci. Preliminary culture growing gram negative rods. Most likely aspiration pneumonitis. The patient is awaiting final sputum, blood cultures, and CXR. Tylenol can be given as needed for fever, and vancomycin can be discontinued as blood cultures are negative for >48 hours. Levofloxacin will be continued on day 3.

The patient is status post AICD placement for primary prevention of tachyarrhythmias due to non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with an ejection fraction of 10%. He experienced one episode of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia in the CCU. His digoxin level was 0.9 on 1/9. The patient will need a PA/lateral CXR once extubated to check lead position. He should be repleted with potassium >4 and magnesium >2. Beta-blocker and digoxin therapy should be continued.

The patient has hyperbilirubinemia, which is likely congestive in nature. His bilirubin level is elevated at 2.1. Given the fever, cholecystitis has been ruled out, and gallbladder agenesis may be a possibility. The patient's hypotension has resolved, and he has been weaned from Neo. He should be weaned from propofol as soon as possible. Final blood and urine cultures should be followed up, and a Clostridium difficile toxin assay should be checked. Broad coverage antibiotics should be continued until culture results return (vancomycin day 3/levofloxacin day 3).

There are no known coronary artery disease risk factors, and the patient's coronary report is pending. He

Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. The patient has profound biventricular systolic dysfunction, presumably secondary to prior heavy cocaine use, and possibly viral or alcoholic etiology. His left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is 10%, which may be an overestimation. The patient's situation is grave due to his reduced LV stroke work capacity. The patient's PA pressures and wedge pressures were markedly elevated during catheterization. The patient is also morbidly obese and has a history of substance abuse, making cardiac transplantation candidacy questionable.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Systolic CHF: The patient has profound biventricular systolic dysfunction, leading to systolic CHF. This condition can result in fluid accumulation, pulmonary edema, and respiratory distress.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient initially had elevated creatinine levels, indicating renal dysfunction. This can be due to pre-renal causes such as hypotension during procedures or overdiuresis with PO lasix at home. Close monitoring of renal function is necessary to prevent further deterioration.
3. Fever: The patient had a fever on arrival to the CCU, which may be due to recent procedures, traumatic intubation, or aspiration pneumonitis. Monitoring for signs of infection and appropriate

Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He has profound biventricular systolic dysfunction, likely secondary to prior heavy cocaine use. His left ventricular ejection fraction (EF) is 10%, and his mean pulmonary artery pressures are in the low 30s. He is currently on mechanical ventilation with CPAP and has been intubated since the day of the procedure.

The patient has a history of morbid obesity and substance abuse, which may impact his candidacy for cardiac transplantation. His current medications include beta-blockers, digoxin, and diuretics. He has ongoing renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.7 on admission and 2.1 on day 9, but it is improving. His urine output has improved with the use of Lasix diuresis. He is also on prophylactic antibiotics due to the recent invasive procedures.

The patient's sputum gram stain shows heavy growth of gram-negative rods, and he has been treated empirically with broad-spectrum antibiotics. His fever has resolved, but he remains at risk for further infections due to his immunocompromised state.

Other issues include his difficulty weaning from the ventilator, possibly due to his large body habitus and volume overload. He is also at risk for thromboembolic events due

He has a history of profound biventricular systolic dysfunction, presumably secondary to prior heavy cocaine use, as well as possible viral or alcoholic etiology. The patient's left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is estimated to be around 10%, which may be an overestimation of his true situation. His LV stroke work capacity is profoundly reduced. The patient's PA pressures and wedge pressures during cath were markedly elevated. His morbid obesity and history of substance abuse raise questions about his candidacy for cardiac transplantation.

The patient has been experiencing systolic congestive heart failure (CHF) with profound biventricular systolic dysfunction. He is currently on diuretics, beta-blockers, and digoxin. His renal function has improved, but he remains oliguric. The patient also has a fever, which could be due to aspiration pneumonitis or another infectious cause. His sputum gram stain shows 2+ gram-positive cocci, 2+ gram-negative rods, and 1+ gram-negative diplococci. Blood cultures are pending. Summary:
Based on the provided information, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for this patient:

1. Systolic CHF (Congestive Heart Failure): The patient has profound biventricular systolic dysfunction, which is causing his heart to fail in pumping blood effectively. This can lead to fluid accumulation in the lungs and other parts of the body.

2. Pulmonary Hypertension: Elevated mean PA pressures and wedge pressures indicate high blood pressure in the pulmonary arteries. This can further worsen the patient's heart function and cause respiratory problems.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's initial creatinine levels were elevated, indicating potential kidney dysfunction. This could be due to factors such as hypotension during procedures, overdiuresis with Lasix, or other underlying conditions.

4. Infection: The patient's fever and sputum gram stain results suggest an ongoing infection, most likely aspiration pneumonitis. The presence of gram-positive cocci, gram-negative rods, and gram-negative diplococci indicates a mixed bacterial infection.

5. Thromboembolic Events: Given the patient's immobility and use of SC heparin for DVT prophylaxis, there is a risk of developing blood clots, especially in the deep veins of the legs.

6. Anemia: The patient has known iron deficiency anemia, which may require ongoing management with iron supplements.

7. Hypoventilation: The patient's obesity and respiratory acid

   Assessment and Plan
   24 yo M with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to CCU after failure
   to extubate s/p elective AICD placement and right heart cath.
   .
   # Systolic CHF: Patient with profound biventricular systolic
   dysfunction, presumably secondary to prior heavy cocaine use in year
   prior to CHF diagnosis.  Also possibly viral (was tested at time of
   diagnosis and only positive for RSV) or alcoholic (patient endorses
   weekend binges at most). Cardiac catheterization performed on [**1-10**]
   included myocardial biopsy. TTE of [**1-9**] shows EF of 10% that may be an
   overestimate His situation is grave, as his LV stroke work capacity is
   so profoundly reduced.  [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) 10528**] [**Location (un) 103**] elevated PA pressures and wedge
   pressures during cath were markedly elevated. His morbid obesity and
   history of substance abuse makes cardiac transplantation candidacy
   questionable.
   -  F/U myocardial pathology
   -  Continue Lasix gtt diuresis, currently at 5cc/hr, but will titrate
   up as patient
s I/O
s net even for CCU stay.
   -  Goal diuresis -1 to 1.5 L today, total goal ~10L diuresis
   -  Continue Digoxin, fluid restriction, and when appropriate, a low Na
   diet
   -  Increase Metoprolol from 50 to 75mg TID
   -  Do not check PCWP as catheter placement is not ideal
   -  Consider extubation when PA pressures <20 or RA pressures are <15
   .
   # Failure to extubate: Patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU
   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization on
   [**1-8**]. Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid
   obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume
   overload from patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure, leading
   to elevated pressures. ABG
s demonstrate chronic respiratory acidosis
   with appropriate metabolic compensation, which is consistent with
   patient
s baseline and is likely due to obesity hypoventilation.
   Elevated left and right heart pressures noted on RHC [**1-8**] with severe
   pulmonary hypertension. Cardiac catheterization with swann placement on
   [**1-10**] demonstrated elevated wedge pressures. Mean PA pressures currently
   in the low 30
s.  Patient was put on was transitioned from AC to CPAP
   on [**1-9**].
   - Wean from ventilator when PA pressures are <20 or RA pressures are
   <15
   - Continue Fentanyl/Versed sedation
   - Continue Lasix diuresis
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Resolving. Cre up to 1.7 on admission and up to
   2.1 on [**1-9**] (baseline 1.1). Improving to 1.4 today. On Lasix gtt with
   negative 2L over the past 24 hours. Most likely, his ARF was pre-renal
   in setting of hypotension during the procedure due to
   sedation/intubation, exacerbating poor forward flow in setting of
   depressed EF%. No recent contrast administration.
   - Continue Lasix gtt
   - Goal diuresis 1-1.5L today
   - hold [**Last Name (un) 284**] for now
   - Renally dose all meds, avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Fever: Pt with T to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, spiked to 101.4 on [**1-8**].
   Afebrile since [**1-8**], but elevated temperature this AM to 100.9.
   Vancomycin d/c
d on [**1-11**] as blood cultures negative >48 hours and
   received 4 days of treatment. Sputum culture demonstrates pan-sensitive
   Serratia Marcescens. UA/Ucx negative. Blood cx pending, but NGTD. RUQ
   US: No gallbladder, no cholecystitis. Will reculture and expand
   coverage if spikes.
   - repeat blood, urine cultures
   - f/u blood cultures
   - f/u CXR
   - Tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - Continue Levofloxacin, day 4
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient is s/p AICD placement for primary prevention of
   tachyarrythmias given non-ischemic cardiomyopathy EF of 10%
   (presently). One episode of NSVT in the CCU.  Dig level 0.9 on [**1-9**].
   - will need PA/lateral CXR once patient is extubated to check lead

Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He has profound biventricular systolic dysfunction, presumably secondary to prior heavy cocaine use, as well as viral or alcoholic causes. His left and right heart pressures are elevated, and he has severe pulmonary hypertension. The patient is on CPAP and is being weaned from the ventilator.

The patient has a history of systolic CHF, acute renal failure (resolving), fever, rhythm disturbances, hyperbilirubinemia, hypotension (resolved), and asthma. He also has known iron deficiency anemia and obstructive sleep apnea.

Current medications include Furosemide (Lasix) at 10 mg/hour, Fentanyl, Midazolam (Versed), Famotidine (Pepcid), and Heparin Sodium (prophylaxis). He is also receiving Lasix diuresis, Digoxin, fluid restriction, and a low sodium diet. Metoprolol is being increased from 50 to 75mg TID.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening heart failure, pulmonary edema, further respiratory infections, acute kidney injury, arrhythmias, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's primary diagnosis is acute on chronic systolic heart failure exacerbation, with profound biventricular systolic dysfunction. The patient has a low ejection fraction (EF) of 10% and markedly elevated pulmonary artery pressures. The patient also has a history of substance abuse and morbid obesity, which may affect his candidacy for cardiac transplantation.

Potential Medical Complications:

2. Failure to extubate: The patient was unable to be extubated post-procedure, likely due to extrapulmonary restriction (morbid obesity) and poor lung compliance. Weaning from the ventilator will be challenging, and careful monitoring of PA pressures and RA pressures is necessary.

3. Fever: The patient initially had a fever, which has since resolved. Blood cultures were negative, but there is a concern for a possible infection. Repeat cultures and observation for signs of infection are necessary.

   wedge pressures.  ABG
s demonstrate chronic respiratory acidosis with
   appropriate metabolic compensation, which is consistent with patient
   baseline and is likely due to obesity hypoventilation, however pO2
   decreased, so FiO2 and pressure support increased.

   Serratia Marcescens. Vancomycin held after 4 days of treatment on [**1-11**]
   but patient developed persistent fever on [**1-12**] to 102.9 on Tylenol.
   UA/Ucx negative. Blood cx pending, but NGTD. RUQ US: normal. In the
   context of persistent fever, low SVR, and new hardware placement with
   lines in place, restarted IV Vancomycin with defeverescence.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with a history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the CCU after failing to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He is currently intubated due to profound biventricular systolic dysfunction and has a low ejection fraction of 10%. The patient also has morbid obesity and a history of substance abuse, making cardiac transplantation candidacy questionable. He is experiencing acute-on-chronic systolic CHF exacerbation with elevated PA pressures and wedge pressures. His respiratory status is complicated by obesity hypoventilation syndrome, and he has an infection with pan-sensitive Serratia Marcescens. The patient's renal function is improving, but he has a history of iron deficiency anemia and asthma. He is currently on multiple medications, including diuretics, digoxin, and beta-blockers, for heart failure management.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Failure to extubate: The patient's inability to be extubated in the PACU may indicate a risk of prolonged mechanical ventilation and potential complications associated with being intubated for an extended period.
2. Infection: The patient's persistent fever despite receiving antibiotics suggests the possibility of a persistent infection. This could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction if not appropriately managed.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels on admission and during his hospital stay

Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old morbidly obese male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He has a history of substance abuse and his cardiac function is severely compromised with an ejection fraction (EF) of 10%. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. His condition has been complicated by acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute renal failure, fever, hypernatremia, and hyperbilirubinemia. The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 102.9°F, heart rate 95 bpm, blood pressure 135/65 mmHg, respiratory rate 17 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation 93%, and central venous pressure (CVP) 15 mmHg.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's ARDS may progress further, leading to worsening oxygenation and potential respiratory failure.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function may deteriorate, leading to an increase in creatinine levels and potential need for dialysis.
3. Fever: The patient's persistent fever despite antibiotic treatment suggests a possible infection or other underlying cause, which needs to be investigated further.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, indicating a risk of dehydration and potential neurological complications.

Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male who is currently admitted to the ICU. He has a history of hypertension and congestive heart failure. The patient's chief complaint is a cough. Upon admission, he was found to be febrile, with a temperature of 102 degrees Fahrenheit. He has been experiencing hypernatremia, which is an elevated sodium level in the blood. The patient's vital signs include a heart rate of 95 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 135/65 mmHg to 186/97 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation level of 93%. 

The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the cough. His weight is currently 190.2 kg, which is slightly lower than his admission weight of 200.6 kg. His height is 70 inches. 

The patient is receiving several medications, including midazolam (Versed), fentanyl, and heparin sodium. He is also receiving ICU medications such as famotidine (Pepcid). 

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count of 24.1 K/uL, elevated blood glucose level of 148 mg/dL, elevated potassium level of 5.5 mEq/L, and elevated sodium level of 148 mEq/L. His arterial blood gas (ABG) results indicate a pH of 7.40, PaCO2 of 55 mmHg, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 138. 

The patient's physical examination findings include a temperature of 102 degrees Fahrenheit, blood pressure ranging from 135/65 mmHg to 186/97 mmHg, heart rate of 95 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation level of 93%. His skin and peripheral vascular examination findings are not assessed. 

Based on the information provided, potential medical complications that can arise include ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and hyperglycemia. The patient is already receiving prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcers. VAP prophylaxis includes vancomycin and levofloxacin. 

Please note that the patient's current condition and potential complications should be continuously monitored and managed by the healthcare team.

   Assessment and Plan
   24 yo M with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy admitted to CCU after failure
   to extubate s/p elective AICD placement and right heart
   catheterization.
   .
   # Acute on chronic systolic CHF exacerbation: Patient with profound
   biventricular systolic dysfunction, presumably secondary to prior heavy
   cocaine use in year prior to CHF diagnosis.  Cardiac catheterization
   performed on [**1-10**] included myocardial biopsy. TTE of [**1-9**] shows EF of
   10% that may be an overestimate. [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) 10528**] [**Location (un) 103**] elevated PA pressures and
   wedge pressures during catheterization. His morbid obesity and history
   of substance abuse makes cardiac transplantation candidacy
   questionable.  Diuresis very sensitive to BP, i.e., UOP improves
   significantly when sBP is above 120. CXR demonstrates improved
   pulmonary edema, lower extremity edema improved, length of stay
   negative 4.6L.
   -  Continue Lasix gtt diuresis, goal - 1 L today
   -  F/U myocardial pathology
   -  Eplerenone is structurally similar to spironolactone, so given h/o
   allergy to spironolactone and current rash, would hold off on
   eplerenone
   -  Consider metolazone if UOP poor today
   -  change Metoprolol 50mg TID to carvedilol 3.125mg [**Hospital1 **]
   -  decrease valsartan from 40mg to 20mg daily since pt
s UOP is very
   sensitive to BP
   -  Continue Digoxin
   -  once 3 PIVs are in place today, remove swan now that the pressures
   have been stale
   .
   # Failure to extubate: Patient was unable to be extubated in the PACU
   s/p ICD placement, EP study and right heart cardiac catherization on
   [**1-8**]. Likely in setting of extrapulmonary restriction (morbid
   obesity/large body habitus) and poor lung compliance due to volume
   overload from patient's systolic and diastolic heart failure. Cardiac
   catheterization with swann placement on [**1-10**] demonstrated elevated
   wedge pressures.  ABG
s demonstrate chronic respiratory acidosis with
   appropriate metabolic compensation, which is consistent with patient
   baseline and is likely due to obesity hypoventilation. Today, CXR
   improved, diastolic PA pressures around 20 and edema significantly
   improved.  Vent setting was changed from AC to PS yesterday morning
   [**1-13**], which was turned back to PS last night for respiratory acidosis.
   - Continue Lasix diuresis for goal negative 1L
   - switch back to pressure support w/ ABG
s PRN
   - when more stable, will extubate to BiPAP
   - keep HOB at 30
   - f/u pulmonary recs
   - Continue Fentanyl/Versed sedation for now
   .
   # Fever: Patient with fever to 101.2 on arrival to CCU, Tmax 102.9 on
   [**1-12**] and 101.1 on [**1-13**] after vancomycin was held after 4 days of
   treatment on [**1-11**]. Vanc was re-started on [**1-12**].  Sputum culture
   demonstrates pan-sensitive Serratia Marcescens. UA/Ucx negative. Blood
   cx from [**1-12**] grew GPC, speciation and sensitivities pending. RUQ US:
   normal.  Meds could be responsible to the fever as well.
   - f/u blood cultures GPC speciation and sensitivities
   - Continue Vancomycin, day 3
   - Continue Levofloxacin, day 6
   - will start cefepime today if pt spikes again
   - remove swan catheter if we can get 3 PIVs in
   - f/u CXR
   - Tylenol prn: fever (< 2 grams daily)
   - Continue to monitor for progression in suspected drug rash
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Resolving. Creatinine 1.7 on admission and up to
   2.1 on [**1-9**] (baseline 1.1). Cr stable at 1.2 today. ARF likely [**1-22**] poor
   forward flow in the setting of depressed EF. On Lasix gtt.
   - Lasix gtt with goal negative 1L
   - decrease Valsartan from 40mg to 20mg daily
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient is s/p AICD placement for primary prevention of
   tachyarrythmias given non-ischemic cardiomyopathy EF of 10%
   (presently). One episode of NSVT in the CCU.  Dig level 0.9 on [**1-9**].
   Patient will need PA/lateral CXR once he is extubated to check lead
   position.
   - Replete K > 4 Mg > 2
   - Continue Digoxin 0.25mg daily
   - discontinue Metoprolol 50mg TID, start carvedilol 3.125mg [**Hospital1 **]
   .
   # Hyperbilirubinemia: Stable at 2.2. Etiologies include obstructive and
   infiltrative disease though most likely congestive. Given fever, he was
   ruled out for cholecystitis and may have gallbladder agenesis as it was
   unable to be imaged by CT or US.
   - Trend LFT
   .
   # CORONARIES: No known hx of CAD. No coronary disease reported on
   cardiac catheterization.
   - ASA 325mg daily
   - discontinue Metoprolol 50mg TID, start carvedilol 3.125mg [**Hospital1 **]
   - Valsartan 20mg PO daily
   .
   # Anemia: Known iron deficiency anemia.
   - Trend Hct
   - Ferrous Sulfate 325mg PO TID, on bowel regimen
   - Ascorbic acid 250mg PO TID
   .
   # Asthma: Will start Albuterol 1-2 puffs q6H:PRN wheezing when
   extubated
   .
   # OSA:  Restart nocturnal CPAP once extubated.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Replete with Fiber (Full) - [**2193-1-14**] 04:02 AM 70 mL/hour

Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He has a history of profound biventricular systolic dysfunction, secondary to prior heavy cocaine use. The patient's cardiac catheterization demonstrated elevated PA pressures and wedge pressures. His morbid obesity and history of substance abuse make cardiac transplantation candidacy questionable.

The patient is currently experiencing acute on chronic systolic CHF exacerbation. His TTE showed an ejection fraction (EF) of 10%, which may be an overestimate. The patient's morbid obesity and history of substance abuse make cardiac transplantation candidacy questionable. His current medications include Lasix, valsartan, digoxin, and eplerenone.

The patient has been unable to be extubated since his procedure and is currently on pressure support ventilation with ABG PRN. When more stable, he will be extubated to BiPAP. His HOB will be kept at 30 degrees, and he will receive ongoing pulmonary recommendations.

The patient has a fever of 101.1, which started on arrival to CCU. His sputum culture demonstrates pan-sensitive Serratia Marcescens. UA/Ucx negative. Blood cx from [1-12] grew GPC, speciation and sensitivities pending. RUQ US: normal. The patient is currently receiving vancom

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy and a history of cocaine use. He was admitted to the CCU after failing to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. The patient has been diagnosed with acute on chronic systolic CHF exacerbation, obesity hypoventilation syndrome, fever, acute renal failure, rhythm disturbances, hyperbilirubinemia, and anemia. He is currently on various medications and interventions, including diuretics, beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, and sedation. The patient's condition has shown some improvement with reduced pulmonary edema and lower extremity edema. However, he remains intubated and dependent on mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been intubated for an extended period, increasing the risk of developing VAP.
2. Serratia Marcescens infection: The patient's sputum culture demonstrated pan-sensitive Serratia Marcescens. This bacterium can cause respiratory tract infections, especially in hospitalized patients.
3. GPC bacteremia: The patient's blood culture from January 12th grew Gram-negative bacilli (GNB), which could indicate a bloodstream infection.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's serum creatinine levels have been elevated, suggesting potential kidney dysfunction.
5. Drug rash: The patient has a history

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He has a history of morbid obesity, substance abuse, and an EF of 10% on TTE. He presented with acute-on-chronic systolic CHF exacerbation and respiratory acidosis. The patient has been on various medications including diuretics, digoxin, metoprolol, and spironolactone. He has been experiencing fevers, and his sputum culture showed pan-sensitive Serratia Marcescens. His renal function has improved, but he still has hyperbilirubinemia. The patient's anemia is due to iron deficiency. He also has asthma and OSA, and will be started on albuterol and nocturnal CPAP once extubated.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's persistent fever and positive cultures indicate an ongoing infection, which could lead to sepsis if not treated promptly.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and difficulty weaning off the ventilator suggest a risk of respiratory failure if extubation is attempted prematurely.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's history of acute renal failure and elevated creatinine levels indicate a potential risk of kidney injury, especially if fluid balance is not managed

s demonstrate chronic respiratory acidosis with

s PRN

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy and a history of cocaine use.
- He was admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization.
- The patient has profound biventricular systolic dysfunction with an ejection fraction (EF) of 10%, which may be an overestimate.
- He has morbid obesity and a history of substance abuse, making cardiac transplantation candidacy questionable.
- His diuresis is very sensitive to blood pressure (BP), and his urine output improves significantly when systolic BP is above 120.
- The patient's current medications include carvedilol, valsartan, metoprolol, lasix, digoxin, famotidine, and heparin.
- He has a fever, and his sputum culture demonstrates pan-sensitive Serratia Marcescens.
- His blood culture from 1/12 grew GPC, speciation and sensitivities pending.
- The patient has a blanching lower extremity rash in line with a drug reaction.
- He has acute renal failure, which is resolving with a creatinine level of 1.2 today.
- The patient has had one episode of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) in the CCU.
- He requires ongoing cardiac support, including diuretics and medications for rate control

The patient is a 24-year-old male with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, admitted to the CCU after failure to extubate following an elective AICD placement and right heart catheterization. He has a history of substance abuse and morbid obesity, which makes cardiac transplantation candidacy questionable. The patient is currently experiencing an acute on chronic systolic CHF exacerbation, with profound biventricular systolic dysfunction. His ejection fraction (EF) is 10%, and he has elevated PA pressures and wedge pressures during catheterization. 

The patient's diuresis is very sensitive to blood pressure, with significant improvement in UOP when sBP is above 120. His current medications include Lasix gtt, metolazone, carvedilol, digoxin, and heparin sodium for prophylaxis. 

The patient's fever is suspected to be due to a drug reaction, as he has a blanching lower extremity rash and positive blood cultures for GPC, with speciation and sensitivities pending. 

His renal function is resolving, with a stable creatinine level at 1.2. He also has anemia and asthma, for which he will be started on albuterol when extubated.

   structurally similar to spironolactone, so given h/o allergy to

   -  hold lasix gtt, diamox, metolazone, BB and valsartan for now
   - once BP and UOP recovers, can restart lasix

   -  F/U myocardial pathology
   -  Continue Digoxin
   .
